Problem:
Consider the analytical solution of the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) under initial conditions that can be represented as a Fourier transform. An operation \\( f(u) = u + e^{i\\omega_0 x} \\) is introduced, where \\( \\omega_0 \\) is a constant frequency.

Can we determine the original initial condition \\( u_0 \\) after observing \\( u(x,t) \\) at some time t without knowledge of whether \\( f(u) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowing whether the transformation \\( f(u) \\) was applied, it is impossible to reliably separate the contributions of \\( u_0 \\) and the added \\( e^{i\\omega_0 x} \\) term from the observed temperature distribution, because both evolve under the same heat equation but could form indistinguishable effects depending on their specific forms and the properties of the evolution.
